Recorded:

  • one-note alarm call, sitt, at e.g. 0:00.6 and 0:30.9
  • (flight) call, ist, at e.g. 0:02.1 and 0:16.6
  • two-note alarm call, sitt-itt, at 0:08 and 0:12.8

General observations: Alpine moor with minor bogs, close to a mountain lake. Pipit calls perched on a stone. Flies off at 0:42. Temperature: 18°C/64.4 °F. Westerly wind, moderate breeze.

Recording remarks: The ist-call is commonly referred to as a "flight call". However, in this recording the call was uttered also when the bird was perched.

Sound classification and rendering: NatureGuides, 2020, Birds of Western Palearctic, AppStore.

Recording equipment: Dodotronic Hi-sound Stereo AOL Parabolic Microphone, Sony PCM-A10 Recorder.

recordings.loc: Ireland (near  Whitehead), Mid and East Antrim, Northern Ireland
recordings.rmk: Although I have uploaded the clip as Meadow Pipit, it contains Rock Pipit for comparison. The first part is a a salvo of four Meadow Pipit 'seep' notes, followed immediately by three more.  Meadow Pipits usually utter more than one note and their typical 'handle' is two or three repetitions of the same note (seep-seep;  seep-seep-seep), although I have heard up to seven notes in one blast. If you listen carefully, the very first note is often slightly higher than others in the series, although this usually only becomes discernible on a recording, especially when the pattern is indicated on a sonogram. Rock Pipit generally gives a single note; sometimes two. The recording, after Meadow Pipit, contains a single Rock Pipit call, then - from a different bird - an example of two calls that were made back-to-back. Rock Pipit's note, as well as being in most cases a one-off utterance (or at least not followed up in quick succession) is more forceful than a Meadow Pipit. It seems more 'explosive' with more fizz. To my ears it sounds like the word 'fleece' but without the letter L.  The final part of the clip is the sound made when several Rock Pipits are foraging in the same area. They use this note as a kind of vocal reinforcement of their feeding area - saying 'keep away' to others nearby. The note probably has a social function too - less overtly territorial and just used to denote presence. Blackbirds, when several are feeding in proximity, use a soft 'toot' sound for what seems the same reason - advertising presence and expecting their foraging zone to be respected.

recordings.type: adult, alarm call, call, sex uncertain
recordings.rmk: Ad. with young birds close by.

Recorded:

  • two-note alarm call, sitt-itt, at e.g. 0:18 and 0:39;
  • three-note alarm call, sitt-ti-itt, at e.g. 0:40.7 and 0:06.9;
  • four-note alarm call, sitt-ti-itt[-itt], at e.g. 0:10 and 0:23.3 (the fourth note can hardly be separated when listening);
  • flight call, ist, at e.g. 0:02.2 and 0:16.8.

General observations: Alpine moor with bogs. Close to a small lake. Bird is calling from the ground.

Recording remarks: For a recording with a consistent Meadow pipit one-note alarm call, sitt, listen to XC578646.

Other distinguishable species:

  • European Golden Plover, Pluvialis apricaria, alarm call, püh/toohooh, at e.g. 0:02.8 and 0:45.8.

Sound classification and rendering: NatureGuides, 2020, Birds of Western Palearctic, AppStore

Recording equipment: Dodotronic Hi-sound Stereo AOL Parabolic Microphone, Olympus LS-P4 recorder

Recorded:

  • flight call, ist ist, at 0:01.1
  • one-note alarm call, chi or pi, e.g. at 0:03.9 and 0:25.6
  • two-note alarm call, sitt-itt, at 0:40
  • one-note alarm calls in the background, sitt, like an echo to the main bird's call, at e.g. 0:09.5.

General observations: Alpine moor. Close to a small lake. Sparsely growing birches. Bird flies to a birch and starts calling from a twig. Second bird calling in the background.

Recording remarks: Shirihai and Svensson (2018) describes a short metallic chip call (with some variations) given by Meadow Pipits when breeding. NatureGuides (2020) renders pi as an alarm call when disturbed at nestFor a recording with Meadow Pipit alarm calls with more than one note, listen to XC578647.

Other distinguishable species:

  • Fieldfare, Turdus pilaris, call, schack-schack-schack, at e.g. 0:21.9 [vaguely]

Sound classification and rendering: NatureGuides, 2020, Birds of Western Palearctic, AppStore; Shirihai and Svensson, 2018, Handbook of Western Paleartic Birds - Passerines, Helm.

Recording equipment: Dodotronic Hi-sound Stereo AOL Parabolic Microphone, Olympus LS-P4 Recorder

recordings.loc: Flank of East Mill Tor, Dartmoor, Devon, England
recordings.rmk: Recorded using an Olympus LS-12 and Sennheiser ME66 down in a ditch to try to get out of the wind. The ditch formed part of the old Incline Target Carrier Railway on the eastern flank of East Mill Tor. I have edited out clicks from the microphone moving in the wind and reduced aircraft noise below 400 Hz. There are two meadow pipits: the nearer one calling less often than the further one. Both were perched in grasses on the top edge of the ditch.

recordings.file-name: XC247567-Meadow Pipit, flight call, Inishbofin 14 August 2014 0930.mp3
recordings.rmk: Flight call from a flushed Meadow Pipit. Meadow Pipit, when delivering this call, can vary the number of syllables: normally from two to five syllables in one salvo. Because this bird was flushed, its voice sounds somewhat stressed and it quickly emits six identical notes. In a more relaxed situation, such as when passing overhead, just two or three more 'laid back' syllables is normal.

recordings.file-name: XC188715-Meadow Pipit, adult stress calls, Anvil Cottage, Inishbofin 2014-07-24 0704.mp3
recordings.rmk:
Adult Meadow Pipit behaving by alarm calling and constantly perching in vicinity of tall grass where - presumably - a juvenile was out of sight. The alarm call was punctuated by the species' normal flight notes (the best sequence of flight calls is from 0:29 over the next three seconds as the bird flies away) given when the bird circled briefly before coming back to a perch. 

During late July, many Meadow Pipit families were evident across Inishbofin and encountering an adult  giving these alarm calls meant that fledged young or a nest with young was nearby. The note seems to be a monosyllable but by listening carefully it is possible to distinguish a 'bounce' in the note (also shown in the sonogram) that thickens the sound to become, not two notes, but something more than a pure monosyllable. A comparison can be made with calls given by a Rock Pipit in a similar scenario XC188716. The calls are very alike, although the luxury of listening to them in isolation on xeno-canto does reveal minor differences.

recordings.rmk:
I have recorded this cut in a marsh with flooded and partially flooded ground covered with salicornia sp. 

Anthus species are common in this place, particularly A. spinoletta and A. pratensis; but sometimes also less common Anthus species can be found there.
Please, help me to separate calls of the two species mentioned above and of eventually other Anthus species

The cut presented here is from two birds flushed by myself. Birds seen quite far away.

Thanks,  Marco

recordings.loc: Great Britain (near  Shirley), West Midlands, England
recordings.rmk: No modifications to recording of Meadow Pipit calls made on passage over a suburban garden. The calls were quite loud indicating the bird(s) were were probably no more than 200 meters above the garden. Always difficult to judge the numbers when you have not witnessed the birds in the recording. Experience tells that not all Meadow Pipits passing over the garden call and also that flocks can be larger than the number of calls heard/recorded.

recordings.file-name: XC563124-PIPIT FARLOUSE MSB1 DAILLY RESERVE DE LA PREE 27 05 20 XC.mp3

recordings.rmk: Two birds on migration
Calls from bird on fence post; Curlew in background.
NocMig

Recorded:

  • call, ist üst e.g. 0:01.5
  • song (perched), series of 3-6 notes zi zi zi, starting at 0:07.3
  • flight-call (possibly from a second bird), ist-ist-ist, at 0:24

General observations: Pasture close to a sea bay. Meadow pipit sits on the branch of a dead oak tree, calling and singing.

Other distinguishable species:

  • Northern Lapwing, Vanellus vanellus, song, at e.g. 0:01.6
  • Eurasian Skylark, Alauda arvensis, song, at 0:11.7
  • Common Snipe, Gallinago gallinago , song, hühühühühühühü, at 0:12.6
  • Great Spotted Woodpecker Dendrocopos major, drumming, at 0:20 (vaguely)

Sound classification and rendering: Svensson, Mullarney and Zetterström, 2009, Collins Bird Guide, Second Edition, HarperCollinsPublishers

Recording equipment: Dodotronic Hi-sound Stereo AOL Parabolic Microphone, Zoom H5 Recorder

recordings.rmk:
I had forgot my ZOOM H5 Handy recorder in my car so recorded with my LG Phone


I think this is a call

At 900m above sealevel. On Nuolja in Abisko National Park. Maybe 200meter from the cableway station.

I could hear the bird and I made the recording that I was playing trying to get the bird closer for a picture which I failed with.

[Picture 1](http://www.aladdin.st/bird-watching/sweden/93.jpg)

recordings.file-name: XC393530-flyover Meadow Pipit near Glenville 28th October 2017_HH.mp3
recordings.rmk: Bird calling as it flew overhead.

Does not sound entirely classic to typical meadow pipit the last few weeks - some even with a rock pipit similar call or sometimes a call resembling (though vaguely) buff-bellied pipit (Anthus rubescens) - so was thinking are these eastern birds.
Filtering option 'high pass' used in Audacity. In addition, a volume increase applied.
Bird on migration.

Call of birds (two or three individual) on migration.
Filtering option 'high pass' used (in two sections) in Audacity. In addition, a volume increase applied.
